overview.protocol: IPMVP Option B (Retrofit Isolation: All Parameter Measurement)
overview.m_and_v_patent: US11062404B2 - Determining Savings in Climate Control Systems

inclusion_criteria: Equipment operating as designed without mechanical issues
Equipment meeting minimum operating conditions for valid M&V
Complete pre-treatment and post-treatment measurement data
PE certification obtainable for the measurement
Customer consent and participation in measurement process
exclusion_criteria: Equipment with mechanical failures or broken components
Equipment operating outside acceptable engineering criteria
Sites where client withdrew before completion
Equipment with refrigerant leaks or charge issues
Compressor or motor failures discovered during testing
case_selection_criteria.rationale: PermaFrost NMR is a chemical surface treatment. When applied to mechanically functional equipment operating within design parameters, the treatment reliably restores thermal transfer efficiency by removing oil fouling from heat exchanger surfaces and creating a permanent thermal barrier. Excluding equipment with mechanical issues is standard IPMVP practice - you cannot measure the effect of a chemical treatment on equipment with unrelated mechanical failures.
case_selection_criteria.pe_role: Licensed Professional Engineers reviewed each case and excluded measurements that lacked minimum operating conditions for valid M&V assessment per IPMVP protocols

success_rate_explanation.observed_rate: 100% success rate on included case studies
scientific_basis: PermaFrost NMR is a chemical treatment, not a mechanical repair
Oil fouling affects virtually all refrigeration systems over time (ASHRAE RP-751)
Treatment chemically displaces oil from metal surfaces
Treatment creates permanent molecular bond with metal (nano-molecular heat sink)
If equipment is mechanically functional, oil fouling exists, therefore treatment works

organizations: China National Lab A (China National Lab)
Major Appliance Mfg A Home Products
third_party_validation.note: All five independent labs confirmed measurable efficiency improvements

success_rate_explanation.why_100_percent_is_expected: The 100% success rate is not anomalous - it reflects the nature of the treatment. A chemical that removes oil fouling will improve thermal transfer on any system that has oil fouling. Since oil fouling is universal in refrigeration systems (documented in ASHRAE research RP-751 and RP-601), the treatment is effective on any mechanically functional system.

high_savings_cases.description: Savings exceeding 50% are possible when equipment has accumulated significant contaminants due to poor maintenance practices
high_savings_cases.mechanism: The treatment removes accumulated thermal barriers, resulting in dramatic efficiency restoration

example.explanation: Severe contamination from deferred maintenance. Capacity restoration from 2.6 to 5.85 tons reflects removal of accumulated thermal barriers that had reduced the system to 44% of design capacity.

outlier_explanation.note: High savings indicate severely degraded equipment that was still mechanically functional - the treatment restored it to near-design efficiency

categories.reason: Equipment mechanical issues discovered during testing
categories.description: Compressor failures, refrigerant leaks, or motor issues found

unusable_records.transparency_note: These records are retained in the raw data for transparency but excluded from statistical analysis per IPMVP protocols

key_measurements: Supply air temperature (dry bulb and wet bulb)
Return air temperature (dry bulb and wet bulb)

calculations.savings: Delta between baseline and post-treatment normalized for conditions

measurement_methodology.weather_normalization: Applied using TMY3 data and degree-day methodology where applicable
